questions.explanation: The Continuous-Time Fourier Transform converts time-domain signals x(t) to frequency-domain representations X(ω). It decomposes signals into sinusoidal components at all frequencies, not just harmonics.

questions.prompt: The CTFT analysis equation is X(ω) =:
questions.explanation: X(ω) = ∫x(t)e^(-jωt)dt integrates over all time from -∞ to +∞. The negative exponent is conventional. This extracts the component at frequency ω from the signal x(t).

questions.prompt: The Fourier transform of δ(t) is:
questions.explanation: F{δ(t)} = ∫δ(t)e^(-jωt)dt = e^0 = 1 for all ω. The impulse contains all frequencies equally—a flat spectrum. This is fundamental: testing with an impulse reveals complete frequency response.

questions.prompt: The Fourier transform of constant x(t) = 1 is:
questions.explanation: A constant (DC) has energy only at ω=0. F{1} = 2πδ(ω). The 2π factor comes from the inverse transform normalization. This is the dual of F{δ(t)}=1.

questions.prompt: For a rect pulse, the CTFT is shaped like:
questions.explanation: F{rect(t/τ)} = τ·sinc(ωτ/2π). Rectangular pulse in time gives sinc in frequency. Narrower pulse = wider sinc. This time-frequency tradeoff is fundamental to signal analysis.
Time shift property: delay by t₀ adds linear phase e^(-jωt₀). Magnitude |X(ω)| unchanged, only phase shifts. Higher frequencies shift more. Used to analyze propagation delays.

questions.prompt: Frequency shifting X(ω-ω₀) in frequency corresponds to:
questions.explanation: Modulation property: multiplying by e^(jω₀t) shifts spectrum to ω₀. This is amplitude modulation. Shifting to higher frequencies is how radio/TV transmission works.

questions.prompt: Convolution in time x*h becomes in frequency:
questions.explanation: Convolution theorem: convolution in time = multiplication in frequency. X(ω)·H(ω) is much simpler than x(t)*h(t). This is the main reason we use Fourier analysis for LTI systems.

questions.prompt: Differentiation dx/dt in frequency domain becomes:
questions.explanation: Differentiation property: d/dt ↔ jω. Higher frequencies amplified by factor ω, phase shifted 90°. This explains why derivatives emphasize high-frequency noise and sharp edges.
Energy is same in both domains: total energy = ∫|x(t)|²dt = (1/2π)∫|X(ω)|²dω. |X(ω)|² is the energy spectral density. Energy is preserved between time and frequency representations.
